inn1.comm: outswinger first up, but a little short. Amla defends well from the crease. Swing in the air, though
Amla moves across to cover the line of an outswinger. Leaves it alone outside off
digs this one short, just outside off, the ball is still moving away. Left alone by Amla
lovely outswinger, just short of that driving length, outside off, Amla punches beautifully, all along the ground, and Williamson makes a diving save at cover. Great play all around
a bit of a tangle there for Amla. Southee seems to have bowled that cross-seam straighter delivery even as Amla looks to move across to cover an outswinger. He keeps this out, though
maiden over to get this baby rocking. Short of a length, just outside off, pushed to cover-point
oh what a jaffa first ball. Boult on money first up. This is unplayable. Moving away against the angle, from just outside off. He has to play at it. Beaten by the movement away
luck for South Africa. There are three slips waiting, Boult has bowled another swinging delivery, squared him up, taken the edge, but it goes low and wide of third slip for four
full and wide, swinging away, left alone
full, really full, swinging away, squeezed out square of third man for a couple. A more confident stroke this time

De Kock has all the luck today. Ronchi has dropped him. Really full, swinging away, from middle and off. De Kock plays to leg, gets a regulation edge, low between keeper and first slip. Ronchi slightly late to move, dives to his left, and ends up deflecting it away from the slip
nearly again. This time he swings it in towards de Kock, who gets a massive inside edge that falls short of short midwicket
short of a length, just outside off, defended

oh New Zealand. Another chance gone abegging. Lovely bouncer from Southee after seven outswinging dots. Amla hooks, gets a top edge, and it hangs up in the air. Goes to long leg, but Boult - he of spectacular catches - is slow to move, and his dive in the end is not enough
full outswinger, left alone
more luck for South Africa. Amla is looking to leave this outswinger alone, but is late at doing that, and the ball comes and hits his bat. It falls short of second slip, though
impatience. Impatience. Too full, too straight, is he looking for the magic ball? Amla loves it, though. "Amla-vin' it," he says, and glances it to the short fine-leg boundary for a four
wide on the crease, too straight, too full, clipped away for four more through midwicket
not if you go by this delivery. Lovely delivery. Left-armer's outswinger. Dips a little on him, pitches on off, and moves away significantly. Beats the outside edge
moves across this time, works this with the angle in, gets a single to deep midwicket
a bouncer. Seems like a plan against Amla? Chest high, middle and leg. Amla ducks it

bowled'im. Boult dropped Amla. He has taken out Amla. Follows that bouncer up with a full swinging delivery. No feet from Amla. He drives away from the body, giving the ball time to swing back in. The ball takes the inside edge, and cannons into the middle stump. Eden Park has come alive again. What a start to the match
length ball, on off, angling across. Left alone

big hooping swinging yorker. This is like a possessed dog going at his toe. And hasn't du Plessis played it well? The bat comes down at the right time, and clips this wide of that short square leg for four
on a length, holds its line in front of the stumps. Defended to leg
too straight, helped away for a single to long leg
late outswinger, starts well outside off, du Plessis can leave this alone easily
short of a length, outside off, no movement. Du Plessis moves back and across to defend
wide on the crease to push in an outswinger. This one starts well outside off again, which means du Plessis can watch it go
short of a length, outside off, allowed to go through to the keeper
short of a length, angling in, gets an inside edge onto the pad
no swing this time, worked away with the angle. Off strike now
full outside off, wide enough to be left alone
and now that square leg who had moved next to the umpire saves the single as this one swings too straight into the pads
the sucker ball. Real full one outside off. Dipping on him. Asking him to drive. Du Plessis says no
on a length, outside off, holds its line a touch, but starts to wide to make du Plessis play
short of a length, some swing back into him, runs off the inside half of the bat to short midwicket
full big outswinger, but starts outside leg. Easy call for a wide
full, swinging in towards off and middle, hits the inside half of the bat again. Goes to short midwicket
short ball, controls it well, rolls the wrists on the pull, gets a single to deep midwicket
short of a length, widish, du Plessis pushes at it away from the body. NZ excited about this. Nerves, they reckon?
full outswinger. Pushed back at Southee
cross-seam delivery, angling in, pushed wide of mid-on for one
length ball, on off, slight angle away. Defended off the front foot
short of a length, tucked away off the hip, to square leg
waits for this length ball to arrive, opens the face late, gets a single wide of third slip
on a length, just outside off, no swing. Defended off the front foot

Nervous de Kock has found third man to perfection. New Zealand have been all over him, he has been dropped once, but now that the ball has just about stopped swinging, de Kock has thrown it away. Jumps at a full ball from Boult, makes a little too much room, swings hard, gets a thick edge, and Southee doesn't have to move at ll. Boult has now gone past Geoff Allott's record for most wickets by a NZer in a single World Cup
and this one is a goodie. On a length, just outside off, makes him play the angle, but holds its line. Squares him up and beats him
short of a length first ball, at 135ks, angling in, dropped to leg for one
short of a length again, 135ks, Rossouw pushes this wide of point for a single
fuller, gets some swing, pushed to short midwicket, and they run because Elliott has some way to come in from mid-on. They make it easily in the end
full and straight, no room, defended back to him
swing back in as Henry pounds this length ball in at 140ks. Defended to leg
wide length ball, driven on the up, but straight to extra cover
short of a length, effort ball, rising towards the chest, du Plessis defends arching back a little
full, no swing, defended back to him
short of a length, angling in, defended from the crease followed by a loud and clear shout of "no"
this is more deliberate than lucky, I think. Short of a length, wide, he opens the face late. Maybe not intended as fine so as to beat third man, but he will get four
fuller this time, driven straight to mid-off
on a length, just outside off, runs this down to third man for a single
this is Kallis-like reaction from du Plessis. Short of a length, heavy ball, a little extra bounce. Hits the shoulder of the defensive bat. His head falls back a touch upon impact
on a length, the speed gun not doing him absolute justice, this is clocked at 145ks, but he is absolutely pounding them in, Shane Bond style. Defended solidly
on a length, outside off, left alone. A tight leave but eventually a good leave
length-ball outswinger, 140ks. Du Plessis watches it through to the keeper

full outswinger, driven down the ground, Elliott flies from wide mid-on to not only save four runs, he even almost catches Rossouw backing up too far. Well done Ian Gould for getting out of the way of the throw at such short notice. It misses, though
really fast outswinger, just outside off, leaving him late, and going away fast. Beats the edge
on a length, angling in, defended back to him
again just the angle back in, defended to mid-on
on a length, just outside off, defended back to him this time
and he must have seen a boundary option as he sees a wide length ball. He drives it on the up, but can't get it past Elliott at short cover-point. Elliott has been an absolute livewire today

inswinging yorker, he digs it out, the pitch is hard, the ball bounces over the bowler's head, the ball is hurtling across for four but not as hard as McCullum. He chases hard, flies at the last moment and keeps it in. Old man Vettori has matched him pace for pace in the chase, and throws this back. Nearly misses a direct hit
tucked away off the hip for a single
outswinger at 140ks, just outside off, left alone
this one comes in with the angle, at 138ks, du Plessis defends this back to him. Goes for a stroll to square leg
back to the outswinger, 140ks, he has seen this early and let this go through to the keeper
stays back to a length ball, punches this down to mid-off
really full, 138ks, on off, flicked back at him, Henry gets a hand to it
short of a length, angling in, stays a touch low. Eden Park rises for a second successive maiden from the young man. What a pick he has been so far
short of a length, angling in, punched away through midwicket. Dan the Man Vettori gives it a great chase. Slides perfectly in the end to keep it in and save a run
pulled away. Du Plessis shows he might be in. Only slightly short, and he has short-armed him through midwicket. Another chase for Vettori
beautiful shot. This Rossouw is some batsman. On a length, angling in, he punches this on the up. Mid-on is wide. This is four from the moment he has made this sweet connection
short ball, pulled away to deep square for one
moves across to a length ball to flick it to leg. Finds Elliott at square leg
short of a length, outside off, punched past point for a single
full, too straight this time, flicked away to deep square leg for one
full and straight, quick again, defended solidly by Rossouw
on a length, punched away to deep point for one
full wide outswinger, du Plessis follows it, gets an inside edge to fine leg. A soft inside edge
full and straight, driven through the line, but straight to mid-on. Rossouw is striking them clean as today
another lovely looking drive from Rossouw. Very punchy. He looks confident. Finds mid-off, though
goes back to a quick length ball, and is beaten on the punch
short of a length, into the pads, worked away for a single
quick length ball, defended around the corner
opens the face on a length ball, gets a single to point
full, swerving in, driven down the ground, but not past the diving short straight midwicket
again the ball swerves in with the arm, worked to deep square leg for a single
tries a bouncer for the first time today, but it is a wide down leg side
short again, at 135ks, he rolls his wrists on the pull, gets a single
on a length, middle and off, left alone. It angles away to pass by where the fifth stump would have been
full again, just outside off, shapes back in to hit the inside half of the game
on a length, middle and leg, defended to midwicket off the back foot
stays on a length, close to off, and quick with slight shape back in. Defended to cover
punched straight of mid-off, calls early, rushes through for a single that he makes easily
fired away down the leg side. Big wides. Ronchi a little slow in getting around. That's a blemish in the field
on a length, middle and leg, defended
runs off the outside half of the bat as he angles this across. Rossouw gets a single to point
slower in the air, but too straight, concedes a single to leg
quick, into the pads, turned around to short fine leg
tossed up on off, punched to short cover
short of a length, punched down the ground nicely, but can't get it past the diving short straight midwicket
du Plessis moves across to defend a length ball. There is some shape on this
on a length, just outside off, du Plessis defends from the crease
moves across to push this full towards mid-on where they pick on Vettori and take the quick single easily
on a length, on off, stays back to defend it

oh a mis-hit from Rossouw. He has looked so good today. He might have earned these lucky runs. Full and swinging in, Rossouw drives away from the body, gets an inside edge, and it goes fine of fine leg
looks for the yorker, nearly squeezes this past the bat, but Rossouw keeps it out
slower through the air now, gets some turn consequently, goes off the outside half to short third man
du Plessis leaves his crease, is not quite to the pitch of the ball, defends it to short cover
shorter, flatter, pushed to deep cover for one
nicely tossed up, on off, holds its line, defended to cover
looks for the reverse, he fires it down the pads. Outside leg, beats him, hits Ronchi's pad. Good umpiring to not call it a wide
quick length ball, defended to leg. Crowd cheers on this over from Vettori. Just the one off
full outswinger, dipping on him, moving away, driven to short cover for a crowd catch
on a length, just outside off, du Plessis looks to run this behind square, finds gully

lovely shot. Du Plessis gets free of some of the pressure. Dances down at him, not quite to the pitch of the ball, but chips it nicely over mid-off. Fifty for this partnership. Beginning to look a little dangerous for NZ
length ball, angling in, defended to leg
wide outswinger, asking him to follow it and take four runs if he wants to risk an edge. Du Plessis leaves it alone
this time Du Plessis leaves the crease, meets the outswinger on the half-volley, and pushes it for an easy boundary through the vacant mid-off region
a length ball, worked away off the pads for one
slower through the air, beats his flick, hits the pad, but is headed down leg
short of a length, bunted into the leg side for a sharp single
quick delivery, on a length, punched to that short cover
pushed straight of mid-off for another quick single. Some of the running between the wickets between these two has been exceptional
on a length, du Plessis looks to work it to leg, gets a soft leading edge back down the pitch
low full toss, driven to long-on for one

big shout for lbw. Looks pretty straight, but is it pitching within the line of the stumps? This is hitting for sure as du Plessis looks to play across the line, and is beaten. New Zealand haven;t even thought about the review, but this looks like a goodie. I see some turn. This might just have pitched in line. Replays prove me right. It has pitched just in line. Called run but I don't see an edge either
worked to long-on for one
driven down the ground, but not past the diving mid-off
another single to long-on
down the wicket, finds short straight midwicket with the push
slower through the air, defended
fired down the leg side again, but this time Ronchi makes a great collection to save four runs
punched away beautifully, but Anderson's dive at mid-off saves three runs
worked down the ground for an easy single
quick, into the pads, worked away to deep backward square
slows this down, no turn, though, and worked around the corner on the leg side
pushed uppishly. Not quite to the pitch of this length ball as he goes hard at it. Avoid the diving Guptill at short cover. Beats him to his left
length ball, angling in, pushed into the vast expanses on the leg side for a single
slower ball, plays it in front of his body, towards short midwicket
full, swinging away, driven to long-on for one
beautiful shot. South Africa saying they won't let the fifth bowler settle. Punches a length ball down the ground, in the air, gets a flat six. Lovely connection. Hardly looking to hit it powerfully
opens the face on a length ball, gets a single
slower ball, dabbed away, but straight to point
short of a length, punched away to long-on for one
down the wicket, drives this to long-on for one
short of a length, flat, turning in to cramp him up. Punched to short cover
takes this from outside leg and reverse-paddles it for a single to short third
full and flat, driven to deep cover
punched down to long-on for another single
starts with a bouncer first up. The crowd boos as it is called wide for height. It is touch and go on height. Rossouw's legs are bent and this has gone just over the head

did anybody say partnership breaker? There is something about Corey. This is a bit of a heavy ball. Rossouw looks to punch this shortish ball, but the extra bounce means it has hit the shoulder of the bat. Guptill at backward point times his jump perfectly to take this one-handed over his head and to his right. A timely wicket for NZ

oh nearly gloved onto the stumps. Anderson bowls short and straight. It is sailing over the stumps when de Villiers' bat comes down. Late into the shot. It hits the glove, goes straight down, but past the stumps
left alone outside off as this angles across
bouncer again, and called wide on height again. Might have been down leg too
down the wicket already, pushes a length ball square on the off side. Can't beat point
full, just outside off, defended to mid-off
down the wicket, Anderson shortens the length, he pulls this in front of square for a single
quick length ball, stays back to punch this in front of deep cover for a couple
full, on off, pushed wide of cover for one
turn for Vettori. The crowd gets into the act. A half appeal from NZ. On a length, it dips, moves away from off, and beats the edge
slightly short of a length, worked around the corner for one
down the wicket, yorks himself up, digs this out for a single to long-on
leaves the crease to drive this to long-on
this is superb running by de Villiers. du Plessis drops a length ball towards that wide slip, but de Villiers calls him through and makes it an easy single. This ball has hardly gone off the pitch
short of a length, outside off, and pushes it wide of cover for another single
short of a length, outside off, this time he has pushed it straight to the fielder on the off side
length ball, angling in, runs this down to the slip. Can't take a single
short ball, pulled away nicely to long leg
full and straight, the bat face turns as he looks to drive. Sends this to short straight midwicket
down the wicket to push this for an easy single to long-off
full and straight, driven inside-out for a single to long-off
slow through the air, bunted around the corner for a single
crowd catch. Down the wicket. Too close to the pitch of the ball. Hit back to Vettori on the bounce
full, fired into the pads, driven to long-on for one
slower through the air, swerving in, defended to midwicket
length ball on off stump, clipped towards square leg for a single
back of a length and outside off, Faf looks to short-arm it towards midwicket, can't connect properly, the ball rolls to the off side
off the back foot, Faf scoops this over mid-on, it wasn't off the middle this time either, it takes him to his fifty, he's withstodd some intense pressure today
pitched up, guided towards backward point
Faf beginning to open up now, he skips a couple of steps down the track and launches this high and over the sightscreen, massive, easily clears the short boundary
clipped towards square leg for two more, remaining overs will be a big test for young Henry, 11 off this one, can Henry keep his composure - and line and length - when the batsmen get after him
steady as ever, length and on off stump, slapped towards deep point
Faf jumps down the crease once more, he looks like he is keen to hit top gear, he connects well but can't beat short extra cover
looks to thump this off the back foot towards point, a thick edge sends it past the keeper and too fine for short third man, races away for four
full ball on the pads, Faf gets his feet out of the way and drives this towards long-on for a single
full toss and that is drilled down the ground, zips past Vettori and the short boundary means long-pff doesn't stand a chance of cutting this off
takes a couple of paces down the track, taps the ball towards cover for a single
McCullum continues to attack, which means mid-on is doubling up as mid-on and midwicket, and de Villiers has punched this short-of-a-length delivery through that gap for four more
wide length ball this time. Just inside the tram line with some shape on it. Left alone
bouncer as he sees de Villiers give him the charge. AB is left swaying out of its line in a hurry
on a length, wide, punched away in front of deep cover for two
full and outside off, de Villiers shuffles across to open up that gap at mid-on once again. New Zealand continuing to be aggressive, but that is costing them runs now
short of a length, no room, but AB makes room by backing away and runs this down to third man for one
short and wide, cut away to deep cover for one
short of a length, sticks into the surface, pushed to short cover
short, wide outside off, and he exposes the sparsely populated leg side by dragging this pull through midwicket. Fifty for this partnership
wide length ball outside off, he has pushed this too far across
short of a length, on the pads, worked to leg for one
short, wide, cut away in front of deep cover for two
slower short ball, outside off, with no midwicket in the circle or a man back. Asking for trouble. Four more through midwicket
wide length ball, he moves across to defend
short of a length, punched in front of square. Elliott misfields at deep cover

there is the half chance New Zealand needed, but they haven't taken it. Pushed straight to short cover, and de Villiers has called him through for what looks like a shocking single. Williamson misses the stumps at the striker's end, but look at de Villiers, he is so quick he might even have made it with that dive. There is dirt in his eyes as he dives. So a bit of a break as he cleans up. This is sensational speed by de Villiers
wide length ball, runs this down to third man for one
short of a length, just outside off, opens the face, gets a single
this is excellent batting. The slip has just moved out, and de Villiers opens the face of the bat to a shortish delivery to get it through that slip region
short of a length, wide, punched to deep cover

Williamson has dropped him. They won;t give you too many chances, New Zealand. This is a wide length ball, hit hard and high to his left at short cover, and it has burst through his hands. This drop could cost them heaps. Future Martin Crowe. Eden Park. WC semi-final. Will history repeat itself?
carnage at Eden Park. Down the wicket to flat-bat this pull over wide long-on for a merciless six. That drop will haunt New Zealand
down the wicket again, drives this to left of mid-off. All along the ground. Four more
and four more. He is on fire here. Leaves the crease again, and drives this length ball between the bowler and mid-off
defends this to leg, but not far enough of Anderson to entertain thoughts of a single
on a length, on off, runs this behind square for a single
full and straight, pushed to mid-off where McCullum comes flying in to hit the stumps direct, but he is well in. This is excellent running
yorker, he is off his feet trying to keep it out, but digs it out for a single
South Africa have brought all the luck with them today. A good sharp bouncer, draws the top edge from de Villiers, and it falls between midwicket and the two men converging in from the deep
yorker, on off, dug out to cover for a dot
low full toss, clipped away for a single to deep square
short of a length, wide, punched away towards deep point for one
on a length, no room, worked around the corner for a single
slower short ball, bunt-pulls it for a single
top shot. Lovely hands. Not much wrong with the ball. Just short of a length, no room, but he arches back, opens the face late, and beats short third man
bouncer, pulled away to deep midwicket for one
yorker gone wrong, a low full toss but still a ball you can't get under, but du Plessis has driven this straight of mid-off for four. Some incredible batting
Henry might be done with the ball for the day but he has saved three runs with a dive to his left at long-on. This is drilled to that short boundary but Henry is excellent

bouncer down the leg side, called a wide despite the half shout for a catch at the wicket. New Zealand have reviewed it. Nigel Llong, the umpire, is interested in the glove as du Plessis pulls. And rightly so, because there is a big deflection off the glove. Snicko has registered a spike too. Du Plessis is a goner. "I have got clear evidence that the ball has touched the glove. I'd like you to reverse your original decision," Llong tells Ian Gould
full and straight, pushed between long-on and deep midwicket. Good running for an easy couple
short ball, pulled down to long-on for one
low full toss, the bat turns in de Villiers' hand, ends up slicing this square of deep cover for a couple
sharp short ball outside off, de Villiers looks to upper-cut, is beaten by the extra bounce. The ball seems to be zipping through now
oh boy what a shot. Southee has missed his yorker length, and Miller has drilled this half-volley straight of long-off. It can't be easy to just come in and start hitting. He is seven off three
that's unlucky. Wide yorker, pretty good delivery, but it runs off the toe end for four to that short third-man boundary
bouncer as Miller looks to give him the charge. That's pretty sharp. Beats the pull with the extra bounce
low full toss with mid-off up. Not clever. He has dropped it over mid-off for four more. Excellent from Miller

that's four more. Mid-off is getting left-, right and centre. Southee continues to go full. This is a slower ball, Miller has mis-hit but it has got enough behind it to go for four after beating McCullum to his left at mid-off
pretty good short ball, hurries him into the sot, pulled away to deep midwicket for one
cruel game. Miller looks to slog at a length ball over midwicket, the angle from round the wicket takes the ball away, takes a thick edge that flies over short third man
bouncer, leg-stump line, pretty high, Rod Tucker at square leg makes a late call for a wide
full and straight, driven to long-on for one
low full toss, hit straight to deep midwicket for one

this is flat-batted for a flat six down the ground. It seems like it has just skimmed the surface. Walks down at Anderson, who pitches it short, but Miller just muscles it down for a six through long-on
another six. AB's fastest-fifty record under threat now. He goes deep into the crease, gets under a length ball, and sends it sailing over deep midwicket for a huge six
short, into the body, pulled to long leg for one
slower ball, he has made him play the check drive, but Miller has still got enough power behind it to beat mid-off and go for four. If Southee is going full, why does he not have the mid-off back?
full and straight, cramps him up, goes for only a single to long-off. Won't get the fastest fifty now
bouncer, draws a rare dot as de Villiers is beaten on the hook
nearly a yorker, dug out to long-on for a single. Nearly a boundary
good sharp bouncer, beats him on the hook, but de Villiers is sharp and steals a bye. This has been a good over so far from the moment he sent mid-off back to the fence
another good bouncer. He has bowled really good five balls. De Villiers is beaten but this time they won't be able to take the bye as Miller is not as quick as de Villiers was
he has shuffled across anticipating a full and wide delivery, and he has anticipated right. Lofts this full ball over wide long-on to move on to 49

he won't get the fastest WC fifty. He won't get the fifty. Miller has backed away a bit to far, Anderson pushes it across again, and he draws the outside edge. Miller has played an excellent hand, though. This has been a capsule-sized annihilation of the attack
Duminy looks to shuffle across and go over short fine leg, but has been beaten by the pace of a short ball from Anderson. Ronchi doesn't allow a bye

another catch dropped. Make it four. It's Nathan McCullum this time. On as a substitute. This is drilled high towards extra cover, NMac hasn't judged the pace well, and it bursts through the hands over his head
this is called a wide. Height, I presume? Anderson goes for the bouncer, and he has let it go
looks to chip it, doesn't get all of it, but he clears extra cover to come back for the second
pulled away wide of long-on, rushes back for the second

inn2.comm: swing first up. This is a lovely cherry first up. Beauty if ever there was one. On a length, middle and off, Guptill has to play at it, and the outswinger takes the thick edge of the bat. Avoids backward point
no he won't. He stays back to defend a shortish ball, and loses a shoe as he slips. Smiles all around as he goes back to wear that shoe again
short of a length, moving away, gives him some room, but beats his cut with extra bounce
McCullum is off. Steyn bowls short again. Gives him a bit of width too. Just short of a length, just wide enough. McCullum stands up tall, and punches this over extra cover for six. Meaty blow
short of a length again, but at his body, not giving him much room. McCullum opens the face, gets a single to third man
fuller this time, Guptill stays back to defend from the crease
McCullum gives him the charge first ball. Philander sees it, digs it in short, beats his hook, but also beats de Kock. That's alarming bounce
this time McCullum stays back. Philander is anticipating another charge, and bowls short, which at his pace is not a great length. And McCullum has gone over long leg for six
Philander continues to bowl short, and even though McCullum has not struck this cleanly he has got enough on it send it for four to square leg on the first bounce
down the track this time, Philander stays on a length, McCullum's head falls away, gets a thick inside edge onto the body
on a length, on off, drilled down the ground, but the mid-off is straight and it is right at the edge of the circle. No run
short of a length, into the pads, McCullum flick-pulls with the front leg in the air, and beats both short fine leg and deep backward square. All along the ground
length-ball outswinger, just outside off it starts. Guptill wants to drive off the back foot. Is beaten
punched to cover, and Guptill is gone if Duminy hits. Guptill has been sent back because there is no single available here. Misses and concedes an overthrow
short of a length but wide, McCullum throws the bat at it, but is beaten by the low bounce. This just skids through
short of a length, on off, punched away nicely, but straight to cover-point
short of a length again, and McCullum doesn't need second invitations. Throws a punch at it, and sends it over cover. One bounce into the fence
well bowled. On a length, no room, but with McCullum all the fielders are sitting back on the 30-yard circle. He pushes this one towards cover for one. Soft hands
and McCullum has thrown him a jab first up. Morkel bowls a length ball, there is no room, it is not easy to swing through this, but he has somehow punched this over mid-on for a one-bounce four
slightly short of a length. The Morkel length. Tucks him up. McCullum looks to go square with the pull. Gets an edge onto the body
slower ball. That is interesting. McCullum has to check it after shaping up for a punch into the covers. Defends this for a dot
short of a length, McCullum stays deep in the crease to pull this down. Not in entire control of it, but he has managed to keep it down and send it through midwicket for four more
this time Morkel has got too big, McCullum is late into the pull, but his shots have meant there is no midwicket inside the circle, and it has fallen safely in that region
wide down the leg side. The crowd cheers it on
Guptill into the act know. This is a full ball, into the pads, he shuffles across to get off-side of the ball, and beautifully clips it past square leg for a four all along the ground
this is one of the best fast bowlers of all time. You don't just charge down the wicket to him, and loft him effortlessly back over his head for a six. McCullum has just done that
wide down the leg side. A huge cheer from the crowd. You can sense the pressure on the bowlers. Any error in length is being punished mercilessly
flatbats it. No respect for Steyn's genius. Just gives him the charge and throws the haymaker at a short ball. Between the bowler and mid-off it goes
bouncer, head high, another Haymaker out of the McCullum stable, and he has sent it thirty rows over long leg. That's fifty for McCullum. This is a gem
would have been a wide down the leg side had McCullum not flicked this leg-side full toss for four fine of fine leg

and now the classic drive. This pick-up truck does a Ross Royce turn. Nothing wrong with this outswinger from Steyn, but he has stayed leg side of it and caressed it between cover-point and cover for four
and he beats the bat. Stop the press. McCullum gives him the charge and makes some room too. Steyn slips in one full outside off. McCullum not able to reach it
flat, into the pads, beats the inside edge, hits his pad while missing leg
bowls a googly that lobs off the top of the pad. They appeal for a bat-pad, the umpire turns them down, and the crowd boos them
driven to mid-off

appeal for lbw, not given, and they have reviewed it. This is a flighted legbreak, he looks to sweep it, and is beaten. Umpire Rod Tucker thinks it might be turning past the off stump. This has pitched leg, turned past the bat, hit him in front of middle, but is bouncing over, according to the Hawkeye. That has surprised everybody. That height has come into play here. It stays not-out
wrong'un, Guptill looks for the loft down the ground, gets a big inside edge onto the pads
another wrong'un, beats him, hits the pad, but is headed down. A maiden. The game turns?

and McCullum is gone. Moving bowlers around has worked. Morkel bowls that awkward length with McCullum charging down the wicket. He is cramped for room as he swings. Doesn't time it at all, and fails to keep it down. Steyn, just taken out of the attack, takes it at mid-on
bouncer here, Williamson ducks under it
short of a length, angling in, defended to leg
full and straight, defended from the crease
punched away square as he pitches short, but he finds point
moves well across, is beaten, but the bounce is taking this over
length ball, he shuffles across a touch, gets a single through midwicket
short of a length, just outside off, beats his inside edge
length ball, middle and leg, defended towards mid-on
short of a length, straight, no room, punched to mid-on
incredible shot. Risky, though. This is a straight full ball, Guptill whips across the line of this. He is dead if he misses, but has made a chunky connection, and gets four to square leg
defends a length ball outside off
on a length, outside off, Williamson moves forward and defends
on a length again, just outside off, Williamson defends solidly
wide half-volley, slightly off-pace, he has to check his drive, and plays it short straight cover along the ground
lovely shot. Morkel only a few inches short of his usual awkward length, and Williamson finds the gap between mid-on and square midwicket perfectly with the pull

Morkel has turned this game around. He has taken two of New Zealand's best batsmen out. Morkel stays short, Williamson looks to pull, the shot is on, but the ball doesn't quite come on, and the bottom edge cannons into the stumps
on a length, just outside off, defended off the front foot
offbreak, into the pads, worked to deep midwicket
flighted on off, pushed to long-on for one
short of a length, pushed just to the left of Amla at square leg, and they pick on him to complete an eventually easy single
nice little clever shot. Gets across to a flat offbreak, and uses all of Duminy's pace to paddle this fine of short fine leg for four
stays back to a flat offbreak, punches it to short midwicket
flighted outside off, pushed to the right of Duminy but he makes a diving save to deny them the single
short of a length, good bounce, outside off so that means Guptill can drop his wrists and stay away from this
short of a length, angling in, punched wide of midwicket for one
short and wide, Taylor loves width usually. Not at his best but Taylor manages to cut this in front of wicket for four. Usually he goes dead square
fuller, on a length, hits the outside edge, but goes wide of second slip. Soft hands means wouldn't have carried to third slip anyway
short of a length, into the body, defended to square leg
late attempt to push at a brute of an outswinger. He is beaten by the sheer pace of it, and the movement takes it away from the edge. Morkel is on fire here
lucky to get away with a slightly short ball. Taylor goes back and cuts, but can't find the gap between backward point and short third man
full, angling in, swept away to long leg

oh ho ho ho that Guptill shot where he doesn't even look up to see where the ball has gone. The shot where he is looking at where the ball used to be, so closely is he watching it. Gets on a knee, and sort of drive-sweeps it over wide long-on for six
short of a length, worked around the corner for one
he moves across to paddle it fine for a single
short of a length, punched down to long-on for one
tucked away off the hip to long leg for one
short of a length, outside off, nicely punched away, but straight to cover
short of a length again, punched to third man for one
stays short of a length, and Guptill flick-pulls this with the front leg in the air. Gets a single to deep backward square leg
fuller, and he gets some movement away. Draws a defensive push from Taylor
fuller still, gets some movement away. Defended back to him. A mock throw back at Taylor from Philander is booed by the crowd
short of a length, pretty slow, worked to short fine leg
short again, googly, punched square on the leg side for a single
tosses up a legbreak on the pads, Taylor bunts this between deep backward square and deep midwicket. Comes back for the sharp second. The crowd cheers on
slower in the air, middle and leg, defended to leg
flatter, into the pads, worked square of short fine leg for one
swept away hard to deep backward square. Steyn fumbles in the deep, but they are only jogging the first so they are not in any position to take the second
lovely delivery. Comes in dead straight, pitches on a length, just outside off, seams away, beats the drive
short of a length, punched to deep cover for one
wide length ball, pushed to that short straight cover
on a length, some seam movement away, defended from the crease. Philander has hit some nice rhythm here
short of a length, slightly wide, punched away, but straight to point
stays in that channel just outside off, and is defended towards mid-on
half-volley, on the pads, pushed to short straight midwicket
swept away, taken away from middle and leg, gets a single to deep backward square
low full toss, dipping on him, pushed to long-on for one
tossed up, Guptill looks like he might sweep, but stays upright, and pushes this to long-on for one
flatter delivery, deflected to backward square leg
googly, the line well outside off is a give-away, Taylor reads it and defends off the front foot
he has nearly cleared out Taylor. Lovely on drive. Philander bowls on a length, on off, and Guptill just swings through the line and goes over Taylor, and between Philander and mid-on
Philander tries the bouncer, Guptill not in control of the pull, but it falls safe towards fine leg

pulls again, this short ball has just sat up. He has pulled it through midwicket. Miller puts in a dive at the fence, his left hand pulls the ball in, but the right sends it over as he comes down in the dive
on a length, it seams back in from around off. That is the Philander threat with seam either way, but Taylor gets a thick inside edge onto the pad
this one seams away towards off after starting around middle. Pushed down to long-on for one
wide length ball, he drives at it away from the body, gets a thick edge, but it goes wide of the man diving at point

run-out. Run-out. Run-out. Remember 2011 quarter-final? Their running between the wickets wasn't great in Wellington either. A lot of hesitation here. A flat legbreak, on off, bunted towards backward point. They both want one, but realise this has gone straight to Amla and firmly too. They pause. That brief hesitation is enough for Amla to throw to de Kock and for de Kock to break the wicket. had they gone ahead without hesitation, like de Villiers did earlier in the day, who knows they might have made it? Taylor is distraught. Not it is his game to see through
a paddle sweep first ball is what he has got. This is fired in, too, so he gets four by using the pace
flighted up on off, defended off the front foot
googly, don't think he has read it off the hand, but defends it off the front foot
swept away to deep backward square for one
tossed up on off, slight turn away from him, defended back to him
no backing away, right behind the line of a length-ball, runs it down to third man for one
short of a length, just outside off, punched to cover-point. Raises his hand up in no immediately after hitting the ball
he shuffles across a touch, Steyn fires one in full and straight. Defended to short straight midwicket
full, just outside off, defended solidly off the front foot
on a length, Taylor moves across to go off-side of the ball, and clips this in front of midwicket for two

lovely shot. A bit of a risk with that front foot moving across, but he is usually confident of making a connection with full and straight balls. The good thing is, he is looking more mid-on than midwicket with this, and closes the face of the bat at the last moment to beat the man at mid-on
down the wicket, bunts this square on the off side for a single
tossed up, on off, dipping, hits the outside half of the defensive bat
tossed up, overpitched, pushed to long-on
full, just outside off, wrong'un, goes off the inside half of the bat to short midwicket
slower through the air, gets some dip, creates distance between him and the pitch of the ball, hits the outside half of the bat
flatter and quicker, worked into the leg side for ine
he shuffles all the way across to just glance this shortish delivery fine to that short fine leg boundary. A bit of a premeditation
Morkel pitches this up, Elliott looks to work it to leg, gets a thick edge towards backward point
that's the awkward Morkel length, rising into the armpit from just short of a length. Fended down
short of a length, wide, but he lets it go
beauty. On a length, just outside off, and nips back in to cut him into two. Bounces over the stumps, though. Elliott needs to get behind the line of the ball
short of a length, gets a bottom edge on the cut, but will concede the single
a length ball, on the pads, they reach halfway mark just before halfway stage in number of overs to go
looks to shuffle across to work this to leg, but the ball doesn't turn, hits the outside half of the bat
across again, Duminy accurate. Defended

oh he has produced the massive wicket. South Africa have brought all the luck today. This is a soft dismissal. The second in a row. Fires this offbreak into the pads, Taylor looks to shuffle across and work this to leg, but he has moved too far across, and has edged it to de Kock, who takes a superb catch. Looking at that catch, there is no luck involved there. This is brilliant because the deflection is big
wide down the leg side
fired into the pads, defended to leg
goes back to punch a length ball past point for one. Pretty close to off when he meets it
short of a length, just a tentative push outside off. Beaten
short of a length, at the stumps, hits the outer half of the bat as he looks to defend
on a length, on off, defended with an open face
this is a Philander special. He keeps landing them on the seam. This pitches short of a length, on off, and nips back in against the angle to beat the inside edge. Just bounces over the stumps
full, half-volley, that should provide him some release. Driven solidly down the ground, with a full face, into the pitch, and straight of mid-off
short of a length, on off, angling away, left alone
sweeps away a full ball to deep backward square
length ball, into the pads, swept away powerfully for four past deep backward square
on a length, outside off, defended to silly point
overpitched, drilled to long-off for one
full, outside leg, and swept away powerfully past short fine leg for four more
tossed up outside off, the bat face turns as he looks to play to long-on, and ends up playing to the short straight midwicket
on a length, on off, defended off the front time
short of a length, on off, no room, defended back to him
on a length, on off, slight nibble away. Has to be watchful to keep this out
on a length, but a touch too straight. Driven down the ground, but finds mid-on
short of a length,pulled away. A short-arm pull. A bit of a risk, but he has gone midwicket who is back. Gets a couple
that's a half-tracker, and is not on at Philander's pace. This is barely above the waist, and Anderson has smacked it over deep forward square leg
legbreak, middle and leg, defended off the front foot
sweeps, beaten as it dips on him just outside off
flatter, skiddy delivery, punched down to long-on
wrong'un, Anderson has not picked it. This is a half-tracker, so he is looking pull, but it turns away, and he lets it go
another wrong'un, and Anderson is not picking them. Beaten on the outside edge as he defends
another wrong'un, punched straight to point
full, on off, pushed to cover
short of a length, opens the face on it, can't get it past point
short of a length, just outside off, holds its line, defended with an open face
half-volley, outside off, and he has driven it with an open face, past cover. Each of his last three overs have featured an ordinary ball in the second half of the over
on a length, slight dip, moving away, Elliott pushes inside the line of it
shuffles across the line to bunt this shortish ball into the leg side for one. More importantly he takes strike against Tahir
flighted, half-volley, driven to long-off for one
legbreak, flat, stays back to punch it off a length. To short straight cover
picks the wrong'un, cuts it, Morkel dives at point, misfields, concedes one
picks the googly, opens the face, guides it in front of short third, takes  the single
short, flat, he pulls this down to wide long-on for one
legbreak, on off, on a length, defended with an open face
short of a length, punched down to long-on for one
half-volley, on the pads, worked around the corner
wide down the leg side
short of a length, into the pads, bunted into the vacant midwicket region, Duminy gives the chase to make sure they get only one
on a length, worked into the leg side for one
would have been a wide half-tracker down the leg side had he not pulled this away for two fine of long leg
wide full toss, Anderson likes what he gets, and sends it sailing over long-off for six. Not the best ball with short straight boundaries
outswinger, middle and leg, pushed to mid-on
quick outswinger, just outside off, Elliott stays leg-side of the ball. Is beaten on the outer edge
on a length, pushed to short cover
beautiful shot. Push-driven on the up, between cover and mid-off. De Villiers gives quick chase, and saves a run. Target under 100. Partnership 50. A big applause from the crowd
full, looking for swing, left alone outside off
looks for his favourite pull shot as Steyn pitches only marginally short of a length. Beaten, as this is not short enough. Goes under his bat
short of a length, on off, punched back to him
full, swinging in, clipped off the toe for a single to deep square leg. Another cheer as NZ reach 200
short of a length, wide, pulled away to long-off for one
swinging into the pads, beats the inside edge, concedes a leg-bye
short of a length, punched back at de Villiers. He lets it slip through, and concedes a single
on a length, holds its line in front of off, flicked to short straight midwicket
full, swinging into his pads, defended off the front foot. Off the inside half of the bat
driven on the up, gets a single to deep cover

Has AB de Villiers missed a run-out? Or has he got it?. Pushed to point, it is Anderson's call, but Elliott sends him back. Anderson is nowhere near the non-striker's end when the throw arrives. On a half-volley. He misses it, and his hand/arm removes the bails. He still has time but is falling over as he collects the ball. He is trying to pluck the stump but he can't. Oh what a moment. Have South Africa made the final, conclusive, crucial mistake on a night of fielding mistakes?
left alone outside off
on a length, outside off, defended to cove r

uses all of Steyn's pace here to get four. This is short of a length and blistering quick. He opens the face, gets it a couple of yards to the right of third man where Morkel dives to no avail. Short boundary, quick outfield
full loosener with mid-off up in the circle. Smashes this drive between the bowler and mid-off
quick length ball, he pulls out of the shot at the last moment as it angles across
on a length, on off, defended back to him
full and straight, no room, defended back to him
again he looks to pull a ball that is slightly short. Beaten on the bottom edge. He just loves this shot
short of a length, outside off, runs this down to third man for one
swinging in, towards middle and leg, he has somehow dabs this to third man for one
outswinger just outside off, Elliott doesn't move close enough to the ball as he pushes. Beaten
short of a length, into the pads, lucky Elliott has not got any bat on it or this could be four to fine leg. They take a leg-bye
opens the face on a length ball, gets a single to third man
loose drive away from the body, on the up, over short cover, gets a couple
half-volley, too straight, driven down the ground, AB de Villiers saves three runs with a dive at mid-on

he has picked on the short boundary. Premeditates this shot superbly. Shuffles across to a length ball, and drags this pick-up shot over square leg for a small six. Just over the rope, but he has picked his field well. There is no fielder there
again shuffles across to work a length ball to deep forward square for one
short of a length, some seam back in from around leg, gets him in the rib
short of a length, dabbed away, Rossouw at point makes sure no run is taken

chips a length ball over extra cover. Not the cleanest connection but it is bouncing into the boundary when de Villiers' electric chase gets him there, but he fails to keep it in. A little clumsy in the end but a very quick chase it is
driven hard of mid-off for a single
wide down the leg side as he fires it down there. Good take from de Kock
half-tracker, wide too, not even a wrong'un, punched between cover-point and point for four. Ordinary ball. Rare from Tahir
driven to long-off. That's fifty for Anderson. Bowls death over. Scores late runs. Gun player. Lucky with the run-out. Job not completed yet
clipped to short fine, Morkel slips but fields it well despite falling over. That's a superb effort
beautiful shot from Elliott to get to his own fifty. How calm has he been. Drives a flighted legbreak inside-out, chipping it over cover. Lovely shot
fires this in full, pushed to long-on for one
overpitched, on the pads, pushed to long-on for another single
full, half-volley, drilled back at him
short of a length, wide, pummelled down the ground, to long-off
looks to slog one across the line, gets an inside edge onto the pad. Half a shout from SA
slogs this shortish delivery away, gets a single to deep midwicket
slugs this shortish delivery wide enough of long-on to come back for the second. The crowd cheers again

nearly a wicket for AB. He nearly drags South Africa back into the bag. The short ball gets a little big on him, Anderson still pulls, and is lucky he has placed left enough of square leg. Not the smartest delivery to bowl, though, given that square leg and fine leg are up
short of a length, outside off, steers it down to third man for one
this is a really mean delivery, rising towards his nose from just short of a length. Hits his glove as he fends. Could have gone anywhere
cut into the pitch, off the leg-stump line, bounces straight to point. Two dots. Pressure building?
lovely delivery. Morkel building pressure. This one is a heavy ball. Just short of a length. Middle and leg. Holds its line, cuts him into two, but sails over the stumps
appeal for a catch down the leg side as Anderson is beaten on the hook. SA appeal. NZ hope for a wide. Crowd boos as the wide is not called. This is a wide down leg really

Morkel has brought them back. Faf du Plesiss was never dropping this. South Africa roar. New Zealand slipping at the last hurdle? This has been a superb over by Morkel. Short of a length, around off, the ball gets big on him as he pulls. The top edge is massive. Kisses the moon before it comes back down. Du Plessis takes a lovely safe catch at square leg. Lets out a roar. But hold on. They are checking if this has kissed the spider cam wire on the way down. If it touches, we have a dead ball folks. The replays are inconclusive. In the dark sky with black cables it is hard to tell, and he is asked to walk on. What a farce it is that we have the spidercam. Encroaching upon the playing area. Has a farce been avoided narrowly? Conversation with the third umpire not relayed this time. How transparent
full, really full, dug out into the pitch, bounces over AB's head for one
on a length, pretty straight. Pushed back to hi. De Villiers has bowled gun overs here
Ronchi is a straight hitter, and they have got long-on pretty straight for him. Driven straight to him for one
bouncer outside off, Elliott is waiting for it, and hooks this over midwicket for a six. Massive relief for New Zealand for the time being
back of a length, outside off, slogged away to deep midwicket for one
full and straight, driven straight again, and Behardien is pretty straight at long-on to keep them down to one
worng'un, he hasn't picked it, but he recovers well as it turns back in. Dabs it out for a single
moves across to flick this, but finds du Plessis at short midwicket
Elliott moves across the line, he bowls full and fast and yorks him up. Valuable dot
flatter delivery, pulled away to the left of Amla at deep midwicket. They don't take his arm on
lovely batting. Ronchi is a touch player. Flat length ball, into the pads, he has just chipped it. Just a caress. No back-lift, no follow-through. Just lifts it over midwicket for four
low full toss, driven hard and down the ground, Rossouw rushes to his right at long-off, and fields. Keeps them down to one. Sensational effort

he has picked out deep midwicket. This is just a length ball, and he has just played an instinctive aerial flick across the line. A nothing shot really, and he has found deep midwicket to perfection. A forgettable night for Ronchi. Dropped de Kock, wasn't great with his collections. Steyn meanwhile is pumped up. South Africa might have their noses ahead here
short of a length, makes room by arching back and cuts this to the right of third man for a couple

slower ball, short of a length, soft hands into the leg side, he rushes back for a risky second, and de Kock has missed him. De Kock is up to the stumps, Rossouw's throw is accurate, but a little too full. De Kock's gloves close early, he doesn't collect the ball, removes the bails with Elliott miles outside the crease
slower ball, clipped away off the pads for a single to fine leg
walks down the wicket, makes room, exposes the stumps, Steyn fires in a yorker, the bat comes down just in time. The NZ fans skipped a beat here. They take the single to point

pressure on New Zealand here. Low full toss, nearly a yorker, dug out to short straight midwicket where AB is in to save the single. Vettori is backing up too far. De Viliiers misses with the throw. They don't get the overthrow because mid-off is in the circle
low full toss from round the wicket, Vettori makes room and drives, Amla makes a diving save at short cover. Saves three runs. What a contest. Everybody is giving it his all

what luck for New Zealand. Elliott plays the pressure shot. He goes back into the crease, premeditating a short ball. Morkel bowls length. He swings. The ball gets big. It lobs up into the night sky. Midwicket goes back. Two fielders from the deep on the leg side rush in. But it falls smack in between
bouncer, Elliott thinks this is his opportunity, but it is a slower bouncer, he gets a bottom edge for one
Steyn saves three there. Vettori moves inside the line to pull this to long leg. Steyn - dodgy hamstring - rushes to the right from fine leg and dives full length to save three

Elliott pulls one back for New Zealand. He stays deep in the crease, moves across too to set himself up. Morkel thinks he wants to leg side, and he bowls full and wide. Elliott instead goes over extra cover. Nails it. Four crucial runs

Collision. Collision. Elliott pulls from outside off, gets a massive top edge between deep backward and fine leg. Behardien gets under it. Duminy rushes in from fine leg. No calling. They have dropped it. In the meanwhile Elliott and Vettori have missed out on the opportunity to take the third because they are standing in the middle of the pitch, waiting to see what happens
Vettori backs away and swings, is beaten by a slower ball, but Elliott charges through to claim the strike
full toss, drilled hard, in the air, on the bounce to cover. They get just the single
Steyn bowls the yorker. The grand old man of NZ cricket Vettori makes room, opens the face with the horizontal bat. Squeezes this out perfectly to the left of third man for four. What a moment
bouncer, Vettori misses the pull, Elliott rushes through for the bye, de Kock Misses at the striker's end, Steyn misses at the non-striker's as Vettori dives

no he doesn't. He hits this over long-on for six. Lets out an almighty roar. All 45000 roar with him. Steyn has bowled length. Why length at this time? Surely you would expect a yorker or a bouncer. Elliott - South African by birth - goes deep into the crease, and lofts this over wide long-in for surely the most important hit he has ever hit in his life. Why would you bowl length, Dale?
